facts.text: Appeal from a judgment and decree of the Patna High Court dated 25th March 1949 in A.S. 2280 of 1948 reversing an appellate decree of the Subordinate Judge in Suit No. 62 of 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from a judgment and decree of the Patna High Court dated 25th March, 1949, in A.S. 2280 of 1948 reversing an appellate decree of the Subordinate Judge in Suit No. 62 of 1948.

facts.text: The respondents have been in occupation as a monthly tenant of several blocks of premises belonging to the appellants at a monthly rental of Rs. 112.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents have been in occupation as a monthly tenant of several blocks of premises belonging to the appellants at a monthly rental of Rs. 112.

facts.text: The rent for the months of March, April and May, 1942, having fallen into arrears.

anchor.surface_text: The rent for the months of March, April and May, 1942, having fallen into arrears, they remitted it along with the rent for June, on 28th June, 1947, by means of two cheques.

facts.text: Respondents remitted arrears along with June rent on 28th June 1947 by two cheques.

anchor.surface_text: they remitted it along with the rent for June, on 28th June, 1947, by means of two cheques. As the appellants did number accept the cheques, on 4th August, 1947, the re- spondents remitted the amount subsequently by postal money order.

facts.text: Appellants did not accept the cheques.

anchor.surface_text: As the appellants did number accept the cheques, on 4th August, 1947, the re- spondents remitted the amount subsequently by postal money order.

facts.text: On 4th August 1947, respondents remitted the amount by postal money order.

anchor.surface_text: As the appellants did number accept the cheques, on 4th August, 1947, the re- spondents remitted the amount subsequently by postal money order.

facts.text: On 12th August 1947, appellants applied to the House Controller for eviction of respondents under section 11(1)(a) of the Bihar Buildings Lease, Rent and Eviction Control Act, 1947 (Bihar Act III of 1947), claiming non-payment of rent.

anchor.surface_text: On 12th August, 1947, the appellants, maintaining that there was number-payment of rent -and hence the respond- ents were liable to be evicted, under section 1-1  1   a  of the Bihar Buildings  Lease, Rent and Eviction  Control Act, 1947  Bihar Act III of 1947 , applied to the House Control- ler for the eviction of the respondents from the premises.

facts.text: On 30th August 1947, respondents deposited the rent up to June in the Office of the House Controller.

anchor.surface_text: On 30th August, 1947, the respondents, whose money order had in the meantime been returned by the appellants, deposited the rent up to the month of June in the Office of the House Controller.

facts.text: House Controller passed order on 10th November 1947 directing eviction of respondents by 10th May 1948, holding non-payment of rent.

anchor.surface_text: Notwithstanding this deposit, the House Controller passed an order on the both November, directing the eviction of the respondents by 10th May, 1948, and holding that they had made themselves liable to eviction by reason of number-payment of rent.

facts.text: Order of House Controller upheld by Commissioner on appeal on 27th April 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the House Controller was upheld by the Commissioner on appeal on the 27th April, 1948, and thereupon the respondents filed the present suit in the Patna Munsifs Court

facts.text: Respondents filed suit in Patna Munsif's Court for declaration that House Controller's order dated 10th November 1947 was illegal, ultra vires and without jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: and thereupon the respondents filed the present suit in the Patna Munsifs Court for a declaration that the order of the ContrOller dated the 10th November, 1947, was illegal, ultra vires and without jurisdiction.

facts.text: Suit No. 62 of 1948 dismissed by Munsif.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was dismissed by the Munsif and his decree was upheld on appeal, but the High Court decreed the suit holding that the order of the Rent Controller was without jurisdiction.

facts.text: Munsif's decree upheld by Subordinate Judge on appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was dismissed by the Munsif and his decree was upheld on appeal, but the High Court decreed the suit holding that the order of the Rent Controller was without jurisdiction.

facts.text: Patna High Court decreed the suit holding the order of Rent Controller without jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was dismissed by the Munsif and his decree was upheld on appeal, but the High Court decreed the suit holding that the order of the Rent Controller was without jurisdiction.

facts.text: High Court granted leave to appellants to appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were thereafter granted leave to appeal by the High Court, and they have accordingly preferred this appeal.

facts.text: At inception of tenancy, respondents paid one month's rent in advance, agreed to adjust on default in payment for full one month.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that at the inception of the tenancy, the respondents had paid one months rent in advance, and it had been agreed between them and the appellants that the advance rent would be adjusted whenever there was default in payment of rent for full one month.

facts.text: Advance payment could be adjusted only for one month's rent, but here rent for three months due.

anchor.surface_text: It was however pointed out that the advance payment companyld be adjusted only for one months rent, but, in the present case, the rent for three months had become due,

facts.text: Appellants contend there was non-payment of rent as rent not paid when due (March due April, April due May).

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out that the rent for the month of March became due in April and the rent for April became due in May, but numberstep was taken by the respondents to pay the arrears until the 28th June, 1947.

facts.text: Respondents contend no non-payment of rent, hence no jurisdiction for eviction.

anchor.surface_text: The main ground on which the respondents have attacked the order of eviction passed by the House Controller is that in fact there was numbernon-payment of rent, and, since numbereviction can be ordered under the Bihar Act unless number-payment is established, the House Controller had numberjurisdiction to order eviction.

facts.text: Money order returned by appellants.

concepts.unlisted_description: Provision restricting eviction of monthly tenants except for non-payment of rent, breach of conditions, subletting without consent, or cessation of employment.

anchor.surface_text: Section 11  1   a  of the Act runs as follows -- Notwithstanding anything contained in any agreement or law to the contrary and subject to the provisions of section 12, where a tenant is in possession of any building, he shall not be liable to be evicted therefrom, whether in execution of a decree or otherwise, except--  a  in the case of a month to month tenant, for non- payment of rent or breach of the conditions of the tenancy, or for subletting the building or any portion thereof without the consent of the landlord, or if he is an employee of the landlord occupying the building as an employee, on his ceasing to be in such employment

anchor.surface_text: in the same manner as is provided in the Code of Civil Procedure.

The law on this subject has been very lucidly stated by Lord Esher M.R. in The Queen v. Commissioners for Special Purposes of the Income Tax 1 , in these words -- When an inferior court or tribunal or body, which has to exercise the power of deciding facts, is first established by Act of Parliament, the legislature has to consider what powers it will give that tribunal or body. It may in effect say that, if a certain state of facts exists and is shown to such tribunal or body before it proceeds to do certain things, it shall have jurisdiction to do such things, but not otherwise. There it is not for them conclusively to decide whether that state of facts exists, and, if they exercise the jurisdiction without its existence, what they do may be questioned, and it will be held that they have acted without jurisdiction. But there is another state of things which may exist. The legislature may intrust the tribunal or body with a jurisdiction, which includes the jurisdiction to determine whether the preliminary state of facts exists as well as the jurisdiction, on finding that it does exist, to proceed further or do something more.

concepts.interpretation: Applied to hold that Bihar Act entrusts Controller with power to decide preliminary fact of non-payment of rent; such decision not question-able in civil court.

concepts.unlisted_label: Tribunal's Jurisdiction to Determine Preliminary Jurisdictional Facts

anchor.surface_text: On the same lines are the following observations of Sir James Colville in The Colonial Bank of Australasia v. Willan 1 , which is a case dealing with the principles on which a writ of certiorari may be issued -- Accordingly, the authorities establish that an adjudication by a Judge having jurisdiction over the subject-matter is, if no defect appears on the face of it, to be taken as conclusive of the facts stated therein and that the Court of Queens Bench will not on certiorari quash such an adjudication on the ground that any such fact, however essential, has been erroneously found.

precedents.case_name: The Queen v. Commissioners for Special Purposes of the Income Tax
precedents.cited_proposition: Legislature may entrust tribunal with jurisdiction to determine preliminary state of facts on which further jurisdiction depends, and if no appeal, its decision cannot be questioned
